etymologies: Old English lufu, of Germanic origin; from an Indo-European root shared by Sanskrit lubhyati ‘desires’, Latin libet ‘it is pleasing’, libido ‘desire’, also by leave and lief

definitions: an intense feeling of deep affection

examples.text: babies fill parents with feelings of love

definitions: a feeling of deep romantic or sexual attachment to someone

examples.text: they were both in love with her
we were slowly falling in love
it was love at first sight

shortDefinitions: strong feeling of affection and sexual attraction

definitions: affectionate greetings conveyed to someone on one's behalf
a formula for ending an affectionate letter

examples.text: take care, lots of love, Judy

definitions: a personified figure of love, often represented as Cupid.
a great interest and pleasure in something

examples.text: we share a love of music

shortDefinitions: great interest and pleasure in something

definitions: a person or thing that one loves

examples.text: she was the love of his life
their two great loves are tobacco and whisky

shortDefinitions: person or thing that one loves

definitions: (in tennis, squash, and some other sports) a score of zero; nil
etymologies: apparently from the phrase play for love (i.e. the love of the game, not for money); folk etymology has connected the word with French l'oeuf ‘egg’, from the resemblance in shape between an egg and a zero

phrases.text: the love that dare not speak its name

examples.text: there were four memorial pages set up by her friends in honour of Phoebe, saying how much they loved and missed her

definitions: feel a deep romantic or sexual attachment to (someone)

examples.text: I do realize that people get married because they love each other

shortDefinitions: feel romantic or sexual attachment to

examples.text: I'd love a cup of tea

phrases.text: the love that dare not speak its name
